If you're [importing animal products from non-EU countries into Great Britain](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/importing-live-animals-or-animal-products-from-non-eu-countries), you need a common health entry document for products (CHED-P).

Animal products include:

- products of animal origin
- germinal products
- animal by-products
- hay and straw
- foodstuffs containing both products of plant origin and processed products of animal origin (‘composite products’)

You must [register and login to the IPAFFS service](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/import-of-products-animals-food-and-feed-system) to:

- complete part 1 of the CHED-A and notify the border control posts that your goods are arriving
- track any controls or decisions by the authorities relating to the goods

[See the collection of guidance and forms for importing living animals or animal products](https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/guidance-on-importing-and-exporting-live-animals-or-animal-products)

There is a ban on importing seal products into the UK, except for items:

- derived from hunts by Inuit or other indigenous communities for their subsistence
- exclusively for personal use by travellers and their families (worn or contained in luggage, or imported at a later 
date)

You must provide an attesting document issued by a recognised body to import under the exemption for Inuit or other 
indigenous communities for their subsistence.

For further information please visit [the guidance on bringing seal products into Great 
Britain](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/bringing-seal-products-into-great-britain).

If your goods are on the [CITES (Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora)](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/cites-imports-and-exports) list, you need a CITES permit or certificate to move the goods into or out of Great Britain. 

You must make sure that the goods are:

- accompanied by the CITES permit or certificate
- imported through a [designated air, land or sea port](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/trading-cites-listed-specimens-through-uk-ports-and-airports), where UK Border Force will check and endorse the CITES permit or certificate

[Find out if your goods are CITES listed and how to apply for a CITES permit or certificate to trade endangered species](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/apply-for-cites-permits-and-certificates-to-trade-endangered-species)

If your waste goods are subject to notification controls, you must make sure that the person who arranges the export of the waste:

  - gets consent from the relevant authority in the country importing or exporting the goods
  - has the correct waste notification documents and movement tracking form for your goods
  
  You must:
    - get consent from the relevant UK environmental regulator in England, Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland to import export the waste
    - pay the relevant fees

Further guidance:
  - [Find out whether waste rules apply to your goods](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/legal-definition-of-waste-guidance).
  - [Find out rules that apply to the import and export of waste]( https://www.gov.uk/guidance/importing-and-exporting-waste).

If your polyamide or melamine plastic kitchenware is from China or Hong Kong, you must:

- find a [Border Control Post (BCP)](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/uk-border-control-posts-animal-and-animal-product-imports) that’s approved to check the goods
- Contact the Port Health Authority at that BCP to identify which documents to upload and steps to take
- Tell/pre-notify the BCP when your consignment is due, at least 2 working days before the estimated arrival date
- have a [declaration](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/eur/2011/284/annex) and laboratory report showing the goods do not release primary aromatic amines and formaldehyde into food

The BCP may also carry out laboratory analysis on your goods.

[Read the Food Standards Agency guidance on importing plastic kitchenware from China and Hong Kong](https://www.food.gov.uk/business-guidance/importing-plastic-kitchenware-from-china-and-hong-kong)

If you import [controlled wood, wood products or isolated bark](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/import-wood-wood-products-or-bark), your goods may be quarantined and inspected at the border.

You must:

- [register with the Forestry Commission](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/register-as-a-professional-operator-to-issue-plant-passports)
- present a [phytosanitary certificate](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/import-wood-wood-products-or-bark#meet-phytosanitary-requirements) for your goods
- [notify the Forestry Commision](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/notice-of-landing-form) before your goods arrive

When your consignment passes inspection at the border you'll get a quarantine release certificate for the goods.

Some composite products are not subject to veterinary checks at the border if they:
- do not contain meat
- contain less than half of their substance of any other processed product

The products must also be:
- shelf-stable at room temperature or cooked/heat treated
- clearly identified as intended for human consumption
- securely packaged or sealed in clean containers
- accompanied by a commercial document and labelled to show the nature, quantity and number of packages of the composite products, country of origin, manufacturer, and ingredients

[Read the Food Standard Agency guidance on importing composite products](https://www.food.gov.uk/business-guidance/importing-composite-products)

The re-importation of certain tiered-priced medicines is illegal in order to prevent trade diversion from a number of low and middle-income countries.

Goods subject to this import control are listed in:
- GB: Annex I of the retained domestic version of [Regulation (EU) 2016/793](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/eur/2016/793/contents), as amended by the [Prevention of Trade Diversion (Key Medicines) (EU Exit) Regulations 2020](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2020/1354/contents/made).
- NI: Annex I of [Regulation (EU) 2016/793](https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32016R0793).

Countries from which the import of these products is restricted are listed in:
- GB: Annex II of the retained domestic version of [Regulation (EU) 2016/793](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/eur/2016/793/contents), as amended by the  [Prevention of Trade Diversion (Key Medicines) (EU Exit) Regulations 2020](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2020/1354/contents/made).
- NI: Annex II of [Regulation (EU) 2016/793](https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32016R0793).

For more information see the [GOV.UK guidance on import controls](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/import-controls).

Goods that are more than 50 years old need an Export Licence. Exporters should check first if their export is 
permitted under the Open General Export Licence (OGEL), which is a bulk licence based on value thresholds. If not, 
the exporter should check whether they hold an Open Individual Export Licence (OIEL). If neither of these apply, then
the exporter should [apply for a Standard Individual Export Licence from the Arts Council's Export Licensing 
Unit.](https://www.artscouncil.org.uk/export-controls/export-licensing#section-1)

If the object you are exporting incorporates certain species of animals and plants and their derivatives (e.g. works 
of art incorporating ivory or plumage) their export is also covered by the Convention on International Trade in 
Endangered Species (CITES). For advice as to whether CITES export permits are required and how to apply, [contact the
Animal Health CITES Team](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/apply-for-cites-permits-and-certificates-to-trade-endangered-species).
An export licence may also be required from the Department for International Trade (DIT) for cultural goods 
classified as firearms, military or paramilitary equipment, regardless of monetary value. For advice, [contact the 
Export Control Joint Unit within DIT.](https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/export-control-joint-unit)

Goods that are more than 50 years old need an Export Licence. Exporters should check first if their export is 
permitted under the Open General Export Licence (OGEL), which is a bulk licence based on value thresholds. If not, 
the exporter should check whether they hold an Open Individual Export Licence (OIEL). If neither of these apply, then
the exporter should [apply for a Standard Individual Export Licence from the Arts Council's Export Licensing 
Unit.](https://www.artscouncil.org.uk/export-controls/export-licensing#section-1)

If the object you are exporting incorporates certain species of animals and plants and their derivatives (e.g. works

If you are exporting military or dual-use goods, then you will need to obtain a standard individual export licence or an open general export licences. A standard individual export licence (SIEL), issued by the Export Control Joint Unit (ECJU), permits the export of certain strategic controlled items.

A SIEL is specific to an exporter and allows shipments of a stated quantity of specified items to a named consignee or end-user. A consignee is an entity who first receives the items. The end-user is the entity which uses the items or incorporates them into another product or a higher-level system. You will need appropriate supporting documentation to get a SIEL.

Open general export licences (OGELs) are also issued by the Export Control Joint Unit (ECJU), part of the Department for International Trade. Check if you can comply with the terms and conditions of an OGEL and register for it on SPIRE. If you cannot comply with the terms and conditions of an OGEL you must apply for a standard individual export licence or open individual export licence (OIEL) on SPIRE.

For further information see [export licences](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/standard-individual-export-licences#:~:text=A%20standard%20individual%20export%20licence,named%20consignee%20or%20end%2Duser).

If you're [importing high-risk food of non-animal origin (HRFNAO) from non-EU countries into Great Britain](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/importing-live-animals-or-animal-products-from-non-eu-countries), you need a common health entry document called CHED-D.

Examples of HRFNAO include:

- peanuts from Bolivia
- raisins from Turkey
- coriander from Vietnam

You must [register and login to IPAFFS](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/import-of-products-animals-food-and-feed-system) to:

- complete part 1 of the CHED-D and notify the border control posts that your goods are arriving
- track any controls or decisions by the authorities relating to the goods

The exporting of radioactive sources is controlled and needs an export licence.

Use the [Goods Checker](https://www.ecochecker.trade.gov.uk/spirefox5live/fox/spire)
to check if you need a licence from the Export Control Joint Unit.

The types of licences needed for radioactive sources are:
- Open General Export Licence
- Standard Individual Export Licence
- Open Individual Export Licence

You may be able to use the Open General Export Licence (OGEL): radioactive sources which allows the export of some
goods from radioactive sources to specific destinations. This also removes the need to apply for an individual licence.

A Standard Individual Export Licence (SIEL) or Open Individual Export Licence (OIEL) will be needed if:
  - the goods are to a destination not covered by OGEL
  - the terms and conditions of the OGEL cannot be met

Register for the OGEL or [apply for an export licence on SPIRE](https://www.spire.trade.gov.uk/spire/fox/espire/LOGIN/login),
the online export licensing system.

You must have a document called a ‘statement of conformity’. This shows that your goods meet all the [EU’s end of waste criteria for scrap.](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/eur/2011/333/introduction) You only need this document if your material is no longer considered to be waste.

If you do not meet all the criteria, or do not have a statement of conformity, your material must be viewed as waste and follow laws around waste. 

[Check if your material is waste.](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/check-if-your-material-is-waste)

You need a [catch certificate](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/importing-or-moving-fish-to-the-uk#import-documents) to import most fish and fishery products into the UK. 
This must be validated by the authority of the country where the fishing vessel is registered or licenced.  You may also need a processing statement or storage document if the product was processed or stored.  
 
Foreign vessels landing catch directly into the UK (except for EU vessels landing into Northern Ireland) will also need to complete a:
- prior notification form
- pre-landing declaration

[Read the guidance on importing fish to the UK](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/importing-or-moving-fish-to-the-uk)

You need a [catch certificate](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/exporting-or-moving-fish-from-the-uk#catch-certificate) to export most fish and fishery products out of the UK. 
  If you land fish directly into EU ports, you’ll also need to complete a:
  - prior notification form 
  - pre-landing declaration
  - the NEAFC Port-State Control forms

If your goods are intended to be 
[used by both civilians and the military (‘dual use’)](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/export-controls-dual-use-items-software-and-technology-goods-for-torture-and-radioactive-sources)
then you may need a licence from the Export Control Joint Unit.

See the [Goods Checker tool](https://www.ecochecker.trade.gov.uk/spirefox5live/fox/spire)
to check if your items are controlled and whether you need an export licence from the Export Control Joint Unit.

Types of licences for dual-use goods include:
- Open General Export Licence
- General Export Authorisation
- Standard Individual Export Licence
- Open Individual Export Licence

You may be able to use one of the open general export licences which allows the export of dual use goods to specific
destinations and removes the need to apply for an individual licence. See the [list of Open General Licences and General Export Authorisations available here](https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/open-general-export-licences-ogels#retained-general-export-authorisations).

If the goods are to a destination not covered by OGEL or you cannot meet the terms and conditions of the OGEL, then a
standard individual export licence (SIEL) or open individual export licence (OIEL) will be needed.

Register for the OGEL or apply for an export licence on 
[SPIRE, the online export licensing system](https://www.spire.trade.gov.uk/spire/fox/espire/LOGIN/login).

You need an import licence if your **nuclear material** falls under sub-chapters 2612 and 2844 of the UK Trade Tariff.

A Declaration of Conformity is required as the goods contain hydrofluorocarbons. You must include a declaration of 
conformity to certify you have enough quota authorisations from a quota holder for the hydrofluorocarbons in the
equipment.

The manufacturer must declare that the hydrofluorocarbons were placed on the market by a producer or importer subject
to [Article 15 to EU Regulation 517/2014](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/eur/2014/517).

The goods must comply with Option C in [EU Regulation 2016/879](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/eur/2016/879).

+++ What is a Declaration of Conformity?
A Declaration of Conformity certifies that you have enough quota authorisations from a quota holder for the HFCs in
the equipment.
+++

For further information, 
[see transferring and authorising F gas quota to another business](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/transferring-and-authorising-f-gas-quota-to-another-business).

You are allowed to import products containing mercury if your goods are:
- not listed in Annex II of  the mercury regulation (for example, special cases of cosmetics or eye products which contain mixtures of mercurial compounds)

[Contact the relevant environmental regulator for further guidance.](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/moving-mercury-and-products-containing-mercury)

You are allowed to export products containing mercury if your goods are not listed in Annex II of the mercury regulation, for example special cases of cosmetics or eye products which contain mixtures of mercury compounds.

Before you can export metallic mercury or mixtures of mercury, you must get written consent from the country you are exporting to.

Further guidance:
  - [Contact the environmental regulator for advice on how to get consent](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/moving-mercury-and-products-containing-mercury).
  - [Find out the rules that apply to the export of mercury, mixtures of mercury, mercury compounds and products containing mercury](https://www.gov.uk/guidance/controls-on-mercury).
